Expectation1: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation1: Opposing counsel pressures for privileged information that could severely harm the client’s position if disclosed.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I stood in the polling station, ballot envelope in hand, when the poll worker noticed a smudge on my signature. “Could you please re-sign this?” she asked, her tone gentle but firm. I hesitated, thinking of the strict instructions I’d read: sign only once, no alterations. As a voter, I wanted to follow every rule, to do my civic duty without error. But as a lawyer, my mind raced with the memory of last week’s trial, when opposing counsel tried to coax privileged information from me, insisting it was just a minor detail. I’d felt the weight of my oath then, the need to protect my client at all costs, even under pressure. Now, standing here, I felt the same tension—two sets of rules, two authorities, both demanding my loyalty. If I re-signed, was I breaking the rules? If I refused, would my vote be tossed aside? My heart pounded as I stared at the envelope, caught between the lawyer’s code of unwavering adherence to protocol and the voter’s trust in the officials guiding me.
